description.narrative: For poor families have suffered insecurity and large scale displacement due to attacks by the Lord's Resistance Army and cattle raids by Karamajong warriors. Life in camps prevented families from accessing farm land, reduced earning opportunities and had profound social consequences, manifestations of which have been high HIV infection and gender based violence rates. With peace families are now returning home and engaging in subsistence agriculture but they are not food secure or able to access to vibrant agricultural markets. National NGOs, local Government, financial services providers and the private sector will work together for sustainable wealth creation. Poor farmers will be supported to improve agricultural, product processing and business skills and understanding of markets. Farmers will be linked to input (e.g. seeds, tools and oxen) providers. This will enable poor families to increase production for consumption and to make better use of the market to increase income. By supporting farmers to work collectively farmers will achieve economies of scale and strengthen position within the value chain and increase voice with Government
